ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 5) Would have liked a couple field trips to solidify the information.
Regarding field trips, we could have spent some time at the Marsh Botanical Gardens. Otherwise, the field trip to the NY Botanical Gardens was great.Hands down, my favorite class.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Dr. Vandebroek is one of the best professors I've had. She is really a leader in her field, but totallyinterested in her students, no matter their level (I was a total beginner). She was always open to questions and always challenged us in our learning. The readings are very good, but the class is extremely practical instead of just theoretical.

I liked the lectures on plant identification. I think they were very useful, especially when we got to practice what we learned and ID plants. I also liked the lectures on plant collecting and the exercise on plant collecting. I found that the final project was a lot of fun and really learned a lot from it.
Lecture and discussion topics were really interesting. Ina's insights from the field. Reading selections were great.

The readings were excellent and just the right amount (about 1/2 to 3/4 day of reading). Also, almost every paper was very interesting and directly relevant to what we covered in class.The teacher's supportiveness and accessibility was exceptional. She was always available before class and was quick to respond to emails. She gave lots of support on our final projects and had fascinating experiences to share with the class regarding her own work as an ethnobotanist.The instructor's presentations were well designed and presented. I especially enjoyed hearing about her own work. Also, the in-class assignment on quantitative ethnobotany worked well and was interesting.All topics were well done.This was a great class, my best this semester.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The final project--at the end of the course, I had a much better sense of how to approach a project, but our final projects were due November 19, so I could not use most of the knowledge I gained through the class in my final project, and I was unhappy with the final product I turned in.
I thought the lectures were dry and wished for more exercises on plant identification.

More attention to the actual body of ethnobotanical knowledge. I would have liked at least 4-5 weeks on plant families and visits to the Marsh Botanical Garden, for example. 3 hours is a long time to sit and discuss from a power point and readings.

The seminar portion of the class was a struggle at first. I had trouble finding the right ways to comment on readings and to draw out meaningful conclusions to discuss. This improved with time though. I would say more clear directions regarding the readings and discussions could help. Also, maybe assigning one reading to each student to lead the discussion would help. Even having each student write a short paragraph about one reading to discuss.Discussion facilitation seemed to improve throughout the term.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: See question 15.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I study environmental history, and have taken many biology classes. This class really combined those interests. I now hope to pursue the field.
I am interested in the relationship between humans and resources, so this course sat perfectly in that space.

I may pursue something related to botany/ethnobotany in the future. I did not know how broad or interesting this topic could be until this class. Now, I see some awareness and understanding of the human relationship to plants as essential for work as a botanist. I wish there were more advanced follow up courses related to plants and people.I would say this course is foundational and integral to my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Related to my research
I heard about the field years ago, and forgot about my interest until I saw the course listing. I thought the readings sounded interesting, and I wanted to take advantage of a visiting professor.
(see above)
Topic looked interesting and the instructor's work was interesting to read.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes.
They exceeded my expecations. I did not expect to gain so much practical knowledge, such as plant collecting and quantitative analysis.

The knowledge and skills I gained exceeded my expectations in every way. This was both more deep and broad than I expected from an introductory course. The course description stated that it would prepare us to work as a junior ethnobotanist: I can say that I feel this is truly the case.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: get to share ideas and brainstorm together. This is one of the reasons I wanted to come back to school.Disadvantages: logistics are a challenge. Not always an efficient use of time.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: it is better to have a background of botany.
Start your project early. Do all the reading--you will get more out of the class.

Take it! A great course, and the readings were excellent. Many of my friends in other classes asked for certain readings after I discussed them outside of class. The topics are universally accessible (you don't have to be a botanist) and after the course you will feel like you know what researchers do. The instructor has done fascinating and meaningful work and is a very socially-minded scientist. She utilizes many opportunities to share this exciting work with her students. She is approachable and very responsive to student inquiries. I always looked forward to this class.
